headline: Copper Nears Record as US-China Optimism Adds to Supply Woes
summary: Signs the world’s top two economies are set to reach an accord this week improve the outlook for consumption of the industrial metal at a time of heightened concerns over production setbacks from South America to Indonesia.  Prices on the London Metal Exchange rose as much as 1.2% to $11,094 a ton, roughly $10 shy of a record reached in May 2024.  Copper has rallied by a quarter this year — recovering from a deep selloff triggered by President Donald Trump’s trade war escalation — as investors focus on a tenuous balance for supplies of the metal that’s key to global electrification efforts.
